channel.title: Drugs & Alcohol
channel.description:
Should alcohol be illegal?
Alcohol is a dangerously addictive drug that brings upon hallucinations and damages both your mental and physical health. So why is it regarded in every society as the OK thing to take? In England it puts a tremendous strain on the NHS, with one in five cases being alcohol related, and it ties up a lot of Police time, with nearly half of all violent cases being alcohol related. So the question is why is alcohol still legal? And is it not hypocritical of those who “despise” drugs to drink alcohol?
Should cannabis be legal?
Based on the above argument, if alcohol is legal why not cannabis? Cannabis can cause a lot of mental health problems later on in life but you cannot overdose with cannabis; it won’t make you violent and is not addictive. Imagine how different a country would be if we didn’t drink but smoked cannabis, would we still see a strain on the NHS by stoners? Would we see the same statistic for cannabis causing violent crime? I’m not saying that cannabis should be legal, but if a far more dangerous drug is, why isn’t it?
Should other drugs, like cocaine, be legal?
* The NHS for those outside the borders of UK, is our national health service

item.title: Drugs & Alcohol
item.dc:creator: mattemuse
item.description:
No shit but the point was that the lobby isn’t going to be anywhere close to the size of the pharmaceutical lobby, which sells a highly expensive product that is impossible to get anywhere else.

Read full topic

item.title: Drugs & Alcohol
item.dc:creator: Codgin
item.description:
but there would be people who could sell it, people who could be taxed for selling it by buying it off a controlled goverment source, that could be even further taxed by having to aquire a license to sell it so they can sell it through implented standards they are taught and watched over. On the spot fines for people trying to sell it without a license. These people get bigger open cafes or factories, they employ people, more jobs are created. Legalizing weed could have a very postive impact on the ecomony

Read full topic

Acristoff:

Because they’re crotchety old men who are afraid of change.

What I can’t get over is that they are to stubborn to see that they’d make more money from the Potential corporations involved in the Marijuana industry than the paycheck they get from the pharmaceutical companies.

item.title: Drugs & Alcohol
item.dc:creator: Deutscher_Scharfschu
item.description:
Congress should face the facts. Marijuana is the number one cash crop in the United States. It Has no long or short term health effects. It’s stalks can be converted in to a cost effective Fuel product that could lesson the burden of foreign Oil imports. Its a Wonder crop in all sense of the word. Last but not least, when life sucks, it makes people feel better. Why on earth would you forbid the sale or use of Marijuana?

Read full topic

item.title: Drugs & Alcohol
item.dc:creator: Oscillating_Obelisk
item.description:
I think that this is extremely relevant to discussion of the effects of decriminalization.

Portugal took the plunge into decriminalization and has emerged a healthier country for it.

Codgin:

I’m not saying you actually see faries, you’re dancing with them, as in your heads in the clouds, giggling at things others cant see etc

That does not happen when smoking pot! snors some weed

item.title: Drugs & Alcohol
item.dc:creator: Codgin
item.description:
I’m not saying you actually see faries, you’re dancing with them, as in your heads in the clouds, giggling at things others cant see etc
As for head spinning I was referring to drink, though with my mates we used to play pro-evo (soccer for the americans) on superfast after a heavy session, and when you stepped away (or collapsed) it felt like you’re head was spinning at an alarming right (maybe it was the collision of moving your eyes fast while feeling incredibly relaxed), it was chilling in a weird way but it was also incredibly frightening

Read full topic

Two different issues :facepalm:

what i was saying was that regeradless of what you are at the time in question it just comes down to common sense, if you’re dancing with the faries don’t drive, if you can’t stand up don’t drive, if the only way to stop the world from spinning round is to lie down don’t drive etc

I hope its the infection!

item.title: Drugs & Alcohol
item.dc:creator: Codgin
item.description:
mattemuse:

How about this - we grow out of our propagandized mindset and accept the scientific research that proves DWH doesn’t cause accidents.

unless you become distracted by shiney things in someone elses car…

I think the whole issue of drink driving and driving high is just a question of common sense. The best way to be sure if you’re capable of driving is if you can ride a pedal bike, try doing it when you’re hammered and if you fall off, you know you’re not safe to drive and you have a scar to remind you

item.title: Drugs & Alcohol
item.dc:creator: Mr.Shadow
item.description:
Someonerandm:

How about this: We don’t drive while under the influence of anything and we can be a happy society and I don’t have to be worried about some drunk/stoned driver going out of his lane and killing me.

That’s what people try to do but it’ll never work. If you’re drunk ( and I mean really, really drunk or high (not just Marijuana but stuff like heroïne, or cocaïne) you often forget you’re not supposed to drive at that time.

Read full topic
